content: This report focuses on USAID's global health programs for child survival and maternal health from FY2001 to FY2008. UNICEF reported a 60% decrease in under-five mortality since 1960, but still, 26,000 children die each day. The majority of childhood deaths occur before age five, with 37% in the neonatal period, totaling about 4 million annual newborn deaths. The critical number of daily deaths among children under five remains high, with 26,000 deaths each day. Most child deaths occur in developing countries, particularly in Africa. Neonatal infections and five infectious diseases are responsible for nearly 90% of all child deaths. Maternal and child health are crucial indicators of overall health conditions, with Millennium Development Goals aiming for a two-thirds reduction in child and maternal mortality. Supporters use Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) to show the link between health and development. MDGs 4 and 5 aim for a two-thirds reduction in child and maternal mortality. Progress in other MDGs like undernourishment (MDG 1) and lack of clean water (MDG 7) affects reaching these goals. UNICEF reports that 62 countries, mostly in Africa, are not progressing towards child survival goals. Countries in Africa need to increase their number of health workers by about 140% to meet the minimum threshold of 2.5 health care professionals per 1,000 people. USAID has committed over $6 billion in support of global child survival efforts, with a significant portion allocated to addressing six major health issues causing child deaths. USAID allocates a significant portion of its child survival funds to address health issues like HIV/AIDS, measles, and neonatal complications, which cause 90% of child deaths in developing countries. Undernutrition contributes to half of these deaths, with studies showing that malnourished children are at a higher risk of dying from infectious diseases. Good nutrition improves child survival, health, and cognitive development, while undernutrition impairs these outcomes. Children who are moderately to severely underweight face a significantly higher risk of death, with studies showing that malnourished children are more susceptible to infectious diseases like measles and severe diarrhea. Good nutrition is crucial for child survival, health, and cognitive development, while undernutrition weakens the immune system. USAID's nutrition programs focus on micronutrient supplementation, fortification, and infant and young child feeding to improve children's health. Micronutrient programs funded by USAID aim to enhance the nutritional content of processed foods with vital immune-building micronutrients. Research on biofortified crops is also supported to improve the micronutrient content of basic foods. These programs are integrated with interventions like safe water and hygiene to address malnutrition-related infant and child deaths. USAID emphasizes the importance of exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months of life to prevent childhood diseases and ensure adequate nutrition. USAID supports exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months of life to prevent childhood diseases. Introducing foods too early or too late can expose infants to disease. USAID has been engaged in malaria eradication efforts since the 1950s, with a focus on the President's Malaria Initiative (PMI) to increase support for international malaria programs. Malaria affects approximately 40% of the world's population, with most cases and deaths in sub-Saharan Africa. The disease is particularly deadly for children, with at least 1 million infants and children under age five in sub-Saharan Africa dying each year from malaria. USAID has been involved in malaria eradication efforts since the 1950s, focusing on the President's Malaria Initiative (PMI) to increase support for international malaria programs. The PMI aims to reduce malaria deaths by 50% in 15 targeted countries by 2010. USAID coordinates all PMI activities in partnership with the CDC. In its first year, PMI reached over 6 million people and within two years, reached over 25 million through activities like indoor residual spraying and distributing insecticide-treated nets. Activities included indoor residual spraying in 10 PMI countries, distributing insecticide-treated nets, training health workers, and purchasing anti-malarial tablets to reduce the impact of malaria in pregnancy. The Clinton Foundation negotiated lower prices for pediatric ARTs at $0.16 per day or $60 per year. PEPFAR implementing agencies have provided care and support to 2.7 million orphans and vulnerable children, with food and nutrition programs reaching 332,000 OVC and 50,000 pregnant or lactating women. PEPFAR's child-focus programs provide care and support to over 332,000 orphans and vulnerable children, as well as pregnant or lactating women and severely malnourished individuals on ART. The programs include training for caregivers, promoting technology use, income-generating activities, and connecting families to essential health care. PEPFAR has committed $1.5 billion for HIV/AIDS care and support, with nearly $191.5 million dedicated to pediatric treatment and over 10 million pregnancies supported with PMTCT services. In FY2006 and FY2007, PEPFAR partnerships allocated $191.5 million for pediatric HIV/AIDS treatment, benefiting 85,900 children. PMTCT services supported over 10 million pregnancies, providing ART to HIV-positive women in 827,000 pregnancies and preventing 157,000 infant HIV infections. USAID's anti-diarrhea programs focus on ORS treatment, hygiene promotion, and training health workers, with over $1.5 billion spent on treating child diarrhea since 2002. USAID's anti-diarrhea programs focus on promoting hygiene, including handwashing with soap, which can reduce diarrhea prevalence among children by 42% to 46%. However, handwashing with soap is not common in poorer communities. USAID supports public-private partnerships to promote hygienic practices like safe water storage, which can reduce diarrhea prevalence by 30% to 40%. USAID supports public-private partnerships to promote handwashing with soap and other hygienic practices, which can reduce diarrhea prevalence by 30% to 40%. Measles immunization is a cost-effective intervention, with the vaccine costing less than $1 per dose. The measles vaccine is often combined with rubella and/or mumps vaccines, with bundled doses costing about $0.65 to $1.50 if bought through UNICEF. The combined measles-rubella (MR) or measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine is cost-effective, with prices ranging from $0.65 to $1.50 per bundled dose if bought through UNICEF. Immunization coverage rates for measles vaccination have improved, with about 80% of children vaccinated in 2006. Global measles mortality decreased by 68% between 2000 and 2006, with significant gains in Africa where cases and deaths fell by 91%. USAID supports immunization programs as one of its greatest public health success stories. A significant reduction in global measles deaths occurred between 2000 and 2006, with a 68% decrease in mortality. The largest gains were seen in Africa, where measles cases and deaths fell by 91%. USAID supports immunization programs by training health workers, strengthening planning capacity, and improving service delivery in over 100 countries. They also partner with organizations like GAVI, the Vaccine Fund, and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation to enhance countries' vaccine administration capacity. Additionally, USAID's maternal health programs aim to ensure healthy pregnancy outcomes in low-resource settings through various interventions. USAID implements various interventions in low-resource environments to address key causes of maternal mortality, including nutritional supplementation, treatment for parasitic worms, immunizations, prevention of mother-to-child HIV transmission, and detection and treatment of syphilis. They advocate for skilled birth attendants at all births and encourage communities to develop emergency obstetric care plans. USAID trains birth attendants to prevent infant deaths and provides community-based maternal health interventions to recognize birth complications and access emergency care. USAID addresses key causes of maternal mortality by implementing interventions such as training birth attendants to manage postpartum hemorrhage and prevent infections, which can prevent a significant percentage of maternal deaths. They also emphasize the importance of skilled birth attendants and emergency obstetric care plans in low-resource environments. Training birth attendants to actively manage the third stage of labor, including controlled traction of the umbilical cord, uterine massage, and the use of oxytocin, can prevent 60% of hemorrhages according to USAID. Sepsis or infections cause nearly 10% of maternal deaths in various regions, with unhygienic delivery practices identified as a key factor. USAID supports efforts to prevent sepsis by distributing delivery kits, ensuring trained attendants are present at each birth, and educating on infection identification and treatment. USAID trains health care providers to recognize and treat complications during childbirth, such as hypertensive disorders, prolonged or obstructed labor, and obstetric fistula. These efforts aim to prevent maternal and infant deaths and long-term disabilities in low-resource settings. Obstetric fistula is a common consequence of prolonged or obstructed labor in low-resource settings, especially among young girls and women who were stunted due to undernourishment. Delaying pregnancy until the girl's pelvic region is fully developed, ensuring access to emergency obstetric care, and performing caesarean surgery when needed can prevent obstetric fistula. USAID has supported fistula prevention and repair programs since 1989 and 2005, respectively, integrating them with other maternal health initiatives to increase access to emergency obstetrical care. USAID has been supporting fistula prevention programs since 1989 and repair programs since 2005. Key activities include increasing access to emergency obstetrical care, training families and community health practitioners to identify labor complications, and reducing stigma about obstetric fistula. Complications from unsafe abortions account for 13% of maternal deaths worldwide, with regional variations. USAID's international family planning programs have helped avert an estimated 4 million maternal deaths over the last 20 years. In Latin America and the Caribbean, unsafe abortions contribute to 12% of maternal deaths, while in Africa, it accounts for about 4% of deaths. USAID's global health programs have helped prevent an estimated 4 million maternal deaths in the last 20 years. Bills introduced in the 110th Congress aimed to improve maternal and child health, including increased funding and requirements for maternal and child services in international HIV/AIDS, TB, and malaria interventions. The Global Leadership Against HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria Reauthorization Act of 2008 authorizes funding for international HIV/AIDS, TB, and malaria interventions, with a focus on providing maternal and child services. The House version emphasizes linkages to NGOs for multi-sectoral approaches, while the Senate version does not mention family planning.
